channel.title: Computer Science Students of Mopar: What Are Your Plans?
channel.description:
We seem to have a lot of computer science students here or at least people who are learning to program. I'm interested in hearing your plans for when you graduate. Are you looking to go down the Indie games development route? Looking to join a big game studio? Applying for one of the big four? Creating a startup? I'm personally planning on working on indie games. I frequent games discussions and was fortunate enough to attend one yesterday with some devs from Valve, Ubisoft and a few other indie studios.
If you're thinking about doing compsci at uni too, feel free to ask any of us questions. It's extremely difficult to decide what you want to do when you leave school. I was lucky enough to study as a mature age student after testing all the waters possible and I'm sure a lot of people here have some sound advice as well.
There's really no reason why we shouldn't be doing a little networking here. If you've already graduated and you're currently working on a decent project, then also feel free to share.
Shoot.

item.title: Computer Science Students of Mopar: What Are Your Plans?
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:31, topic:540572”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=659434.msg4409971#msg4409971 date=1393267318]
I’m only in first-year university up here in Canada studying CS. Since I’m only a first-year, I haven’t actually specialized yet but I have an interest in operating systems and still, the web.

For anyone interested in finding a university in Canada feel free to PM me or something as I can give you some information about some of them.
[/quote]
Actually that’s how it is here in Australia too. You don’t choose a specialization until 2nd year. However when you enroll/apply you nominate a specialization. You’re not required to actually choose the specialization until 2nd year enrollment, but you are required to nominate what you are planning to specialization in.

In my opinion it’s nicer this way. I don’t know how it is Canada but you can elect to take specialization courses as early as your first study period. I took the 2nd year math unit in my first semester of CS.[/quote]

Interesting, however I don’t know if we take the specialization route because looking at what courses I have to take in second year, they are more general CS courses such as: logic and computation, algorithm design, data structures, etc. Nonetheless, in upper years there is a wide variety of courses so I guess specializing can be done in third+ years.

Read full topic
item.source: Computer Science Students of Mopar: What Are Your Plans?

item.title: Computer Science Students of Mopar: What Are Your Plans?
item.dc:creator: @kickingjamie kickingjamie
item.description:
@kickingjamie wrote:

I hope to do sports science in a few years or anything with a focus on sports development based technology. So it could be things like performance analysis systems, tracking systems, scoring systems and so on. I’ve also thought about mobile apps for sport related stuff, like score systems, coaching tools (timers etc), route planners for exercise, timetables for work outs. Even the advertising and media side of sports interests me, I hope to work for people like Sky sports news, BBC news etc.

I think that technology within sport is a very recent development and a job involving them both would be lots of fun. Sport is relying more on technology every year.

I bet you never expected that, huh?

Read full topic
item.source: Computer Science Students of Mopar: What Are Your Plans?

item.title: Computer Science Students of Mopar: What Are Your Plans?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“justaguy, post:20, topic:540572”]I’m only in first-year university up here in Canada studying CS. Since I’m only a first-year, I haven’t actually specialized yet but I have an interest in operating systems and still, the web.

For anyone interested in finding a university in Canada feel free to PM me or something as I can give you some information about some of them.[/quote]
Actually that’s how it is here in Australia too. You don’t choose a specialization until 2nd year. However when you enroll/apply you nominate a specialization. You’re not required to actually choose the specialization until 2nd year enrollment, but you are required to nominate what you are planning to specialization in.

In my opinion it’s nicer this way. I don’t know how it is Canada but you can elect to take specialization courses as early as your first study period. I took the 2nd year math unit in my first semester of CS.

item.title: Computer Science Students of Mopar: What Are Your Plans?
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

Davidi2:

Huh? Why would you care if we could identify you? You post IRL pictures all the time… are you ashamed of the company or something?

There are a few legal issues, and I just don’t want anyone from this site having the ability to contact my employers. I will explain the legal issues privately, if you like.

Read full topic

item.title: Computer Science Students of Mopar: What Are Your Plans?
item.dc:creator: @NewbieNewty Newty
item.description:
@NewbieNewty wrote:

I’m trying to get my associates in information technology through the air force right now. After that I’m getting into a bachelors program at wgu.

I’m also getting industry certs while I’m in the Air Force; all on the Air Force’s dime. I’m in a Cisco CCNA class right now and in a few weeks I’ll be in a Cisco ASA class followed by a Linux+ class. I also get a lot of hands on experience with cisco devices and various windows and linux servers in my work center.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

ok on topic then

im planning on going to a technical college in the fall to start my 4 year shit. 2 years of shit, then get certified in java. after that i plan to go to a university for computer science- not sure if i want to do game design // it // what field, but i know i want to do something with electronics-more than likely something mobile.

currently working and saving up for college funds

item.title: Computer Science Students of Mopar: What Are Your Plans?
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:24, topic:540572”][quote author=Vain_ link=topic=659434.msg4409973#msg4409973 date=1393268571]

[quote author=Ambokile link=topic=659434.msg4409964#msg4409964 date=1393260917]

I’m currently employed in quite a big company as their mobile app developer for their product, but I do help with their main product sometimes. I’m applying to University at the end of 2014, and hopefully I will return to the same company as I really enjoy both the work and the atmosphere there.

What are the working conditions/pay/fellow employees like?

All are perfect, I enjoy working there and I enjoy taking work home to do there. It’s never stressful, if you can’t sort the problem then take a while to sit back and clear your mind. It’s a small team, 10 people or so which makes it better I feel.
[/quote]what big company only has a team of ten people
[/quote]A successful one? Having huge teams benefits nobody.[/quote]Exactly. We have one product. Why do we need more than 5 developers? (the makeup of the team is 5 developers, 2 designers, 2 in the sales team, 1 marketing, and the CEO who is good at everything.)

Read full topic

item.title: Computer Science Students of Mopar: What Are Your Plans?
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

Vain_:

what big company only has a team of ten people

…WhatsApp just got bought out for 300 million per employee…
There are plenty of small development companies. I know a printing company that has 3 people and they bank in 16k a month.

Anyways, I have 3 years left of a GI Bill (was given to me, I never served). I will probably end up enlisting for 4 years to gain another 4 years of GI Bill. The college life is the life for me.

Read full topic

item.title: Computer Science Students of Mopar: What Are Your Plans?
item.dc:creator: @Devinhdl Devinhdl
item.description:
@Devinhdl wrote:

I’m currently in college now, going for a general Associate’s degree and then gearing my Bachelor’s and Master’s towards computer science or programming. After these degrees or even during the schooling aspect of the degrees, I’m planning on joining any company and write programs for them. I’m particularly not wanting to get involved with game development until I feel 100% ready for that. Just a simple job, working with a company’s IT team and writing programs to help further that company’s technical branch.

Programming is something that I love to do, it’s actually quite enjoyable to learn and to be able to get paid to practice my skills would just be amazing.

Read full topic

That’s not too bad for entry really. I wonder how big the market is for developers.
I’m yet to test that.

item.title: Computer Science Students of Mopar: What Are Your Plans?
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:10, topic:540572”]I did IT instead of comp sci. The reason being that it didn’t have a maths component.
Now I work for one of the state governments on the Microsoft Development team. I like my job so far.

Also, love them or hate them, Microsoft has the best tooling around when it comes to software and database development. Visual Studio wipes the floor with every other IDE on the market (across all languages) imo. Mind you, the price tag of the Ultimate version is enough to make you cry. :P[/quote]

Do they pay fairly well? I’ve always wondered what government IT jobs were like pay-wise.

xx matty xx:

I work in tools at rockstar north and program the software used by the mission scripters, testers, artists, etc… It’s pretty relaxed and great pay but gets a bit stressful at crunch time. Also, it’s nice having something with your name on it at the end and actually producing a finished product instead of this ongoing development bullshit.

Interesting! How did you score that one?

Read full topic

item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I did IT instead of comp sci. The reason being that it didn’t have a maths component.
Now I work for one of the state governments on the Microsoft Development team. I like my job so far.

Also, love them or hate them, Microsoft has the best tooling around when it comes to software and database development. Visual Studio wipes the floor with every other IDE on the market (across all languages) imo. Mind you, the price tag of the Ultimate version is enough to make you cry.
